passcheck package

Submodules

passcheck.search module

search.py

This module contains all the functions to convert a string to a SHA-1 password and use the haveibeenpwned API to see whether the password(s) has been compromised. It also contains the __main__ construct to make the module executable.

passcheck.search.count_password_leaked(hashes, hash_to_check)[source]

Checks if there’s any hash suffix in the response passed by request_api_data() that matches the suffix of our password(s) we get from pawned_api_check().

Parameters

  • hashes – The response we get from request_api_data()

  • hash_to_check – The hash suffix from our password(s) we get from pawned_api_check().

Returns

If there’s any matching suffix returns the count of times it has been compromised otherwise returns 0.

passcheck.search.main(args) → None[source]

Iterates over a list of passwords strings and checks whether any of them has been compromised, then prints the results. Two guard clauses are included to prevent misfunction.

Parameters

args – A list of strings

Returns

None

Raises

ValueError – If args is not a list or members of args are not strings.

passcheck.search.pawned_api_check(password)[source]

Converts password(s) to SHA-1 hash and splits it into suffix(first 5 characters) and prefix(remaining 35 characters). Invokes both request_api_data() and count_password_leaked().

Parameters

password – The password we want to use

Returns

The count from count_password_leaked()

passcheck.search.request_api_data(prefix)[source]

Fetches the response of pwnedpasswords-API using a prefix.

Parameters

prefix – The first 5 characters of a SHA-1 password hash (not case sensitive).

Returns

A list of suffixes that match our prefix and a count of the times it has been compromised e.g. 00D4F6E8FA6EECAD2A3AA415EEC418D38EC:2.

Raises

RuntimeError – If API returns any HTTP code different to 200, e.g. HTTP 404.

Module contents

Demo project: passcheck

This project serves mainly as practice for sphinx and apidoc implementation.

The idea is to take any amount of passwords from the user and verify if they’ve been compromised using the API from haveibeenpwned that uses a k-Anonymity model that allows passwords to be searched by a partial hash.

After converting the passwords to SHA-1 we use the API to verify any compromised password(s) and print the results.
